commit_message:
Support rarp protocol for egress table

When vm live-migration is done, at the vm start moment, the
vm will send rarp packet, but the table 71 of openflow will
drop these packets, because they cannot match any flow in
high priority(65 70 80 95), only the priority 10 flow can
match them, and its aciton is drop, so all the rarp packets
will be dropped, and the connectivity will be broken after
live-migration.

Change-Id: Id1cc34f0f544b2cb8cc89af2cb81bb15e4605a0e
Partial-Bug: #1831404
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/661938

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary logic

THT logic which exposed fluentd logging hieradata even when the service
was not enabled was removed, so the logic in rsyslog file_input working
with such data won't ever work.

Change-Id: I58edc44f859a0b46c1b1ae82c453df9f4d2bc487

commit_message:
Add post job for sphix docs

In order to post new documentation we need to have a post job run.
This change adds the sphinx post job needed to publish documentation.

Change-Id: I78c5371fddd23d88630daac1ba7e78e63069d082
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

subject: config_template does not respect yaml multiline as overrides
messages:
[{'account_id': 29865, 'date': '2019-04-24 16:45:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 29865, 'date': '2019-04-24 17:00:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hesitant to say this is resolved completely.
Unsure if splitting on commas if there is also a new line in the string will cause bad side effects in the case where a flow style block is being used. Any advice on this?

Also the PyYaml library does not handle multiline comments very gracefully themselves, hence when we dump the configuration back out it's not in a very nice format.
There are some issues flagged up already in PyYaml:
https://github.com/yaml/pyyaml/issues/240
https://github.com/yaml/pyyaml/issues/246

There do seem to be examples of hacky workarounds:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/45004464/yaml-dump-adding-unwanted-newlines-in-multiline-strings
One of which is to use ruamel library instead...

Perhaps there is a bigger discussion needed here if we want to fully support yaml multilines."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-04-24 17:08:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

This is a good first start. It's not a perfect approach. But I don't have a better approach so I prefer this to be in than nothing."}, {'account_id': 29865, 'date': '2019-04-25 11:32:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-05-22 09:56:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 27679, 'date': '2019-05-22 10:07:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2019-07-08 21:37:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
config_template does not respect yaml multiline as overrides

Added a flag called yml_multilines which when used will not split on
lines that have a newline UNLESS they have a comma.

Change-Id: I90364403e215a67b320dfc7e67a85d47c774e634
Partial-Bug: #1819974

subject: tox: Stop building api-ref docs with the main docs
messages:
[{'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-07-05 15:29:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-07-05 15:34:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Is there a specific reason to not do this? If I remember the reason for doing it was so that it was a one stop shop to make sure the docs target did "all the docs" (which I guess isn't really true since it doesn't do releasenotes).'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-07-05 15:36:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-07-05 15:37:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-07-05 15:41:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Is there a specific reason to not do this? If I remember the reason
 > for doing it was so that it was a one stop shop to make sure the
 > docs target did "all the docs" (which I guess isn't really true
 > since it doesn't do releasenotes).

Mostly for speed, both locally and in the gate. sphinx is already rather slow and it's nice (for me, at least) to be able to build just what I want. Similarly, the gate uses 'tox -e docs' to build the docs that get published to docs.o.o so it's simply building api-ref docs twice here.

I did something similar in nova a while back [1] and I added an 'all-docs' target. Should I add the same here?

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/commit/f49b81fa2bd692583370bab569f25215073a5bc2'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-07-05 15:44:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

> Mostly for speed, both locally and in the gate. sphinx is already
 > rather slow and it's nice (for me, at least) to be able to build
 > just what I want. Similarly, the gate uses 'tox -e docs' to build
 > the docs that get published to docs.o.o so it's simply building
 > api-ref docs twice here.

Did the gate change. Or rather, was there a time when it used a different job for docs building?

In any case, I'm happy with the change you've made. all-docs change would be a useful addition for dev-side work where we want to make sure all the things are happy, but not critical."}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-07-05 15:49:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> > Mostly for speed, both locally and in the gate. sphinx is already
 > > rather slow and it's nice (for me, at least) to be able to build
 > > just what I want. Similarly, the gate uses 'tox -e docs' to build
 > > the docs that get published to docs.o.o so it's simply building
 > > api-ref docs twice here.
 > 
 > Did the gate change. Or rather, was there a time when it used a
 > different job for docs building?

Yup. There was an effort to start building with 'sphinx-build' directly for a while, led by mordred, but that was abandoned for reasons I don't recall.

 > In any case, I'm happy with the change you've made. all-docs change
 > would be a useful addition for dev-side work where we want to make
 > sure all the things are happy, but not critical.

Sure. I won't do it now because _I_ won't personally use it, but if you think it would be useful I can easily respin"}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-07-08 08:18:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-07-08 16:35:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

LGTM'}]

Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

subject: container-replicator: Add a timeout for get_shard_ranges
messages:
[{'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-07-03 17:40:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2019-07-03 20:27:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

(5 comments)

it'll be nice to get this fixed, might be a few other things to cleanup when you're making pep8 happy"}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-07-04 05:29:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(3 comments)

Heh, that's what I get for mostly writing this on the train."}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-07-04 05:30:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2019-07-08 19:55:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

(1 comment)

So I think my original concern with the test was that if some regression made get_shard_ranges rpc to raise an exception this test wouldn't be able to tell the difference between that and a timeout.

But I couldn't find a reasonable way to make get_shard_ranges explode that wasn't covered by some other test.

Slowness in the gate could potentially cause the small 0.001 timeout to pop before the sleep(0.1) fires - but I guess that's testing the timeout regardless of the race so it's unlikely to cause a false failure.

:shipit:"}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-03 17:40:26.000000000', 'message': "container-replicator: Add a timeout for get_shard_ranges

Previously this had no timeout, which meant that the replicator might
hang and fail to make progress indefinitely while trying to receive
shard ranges.

While we're at it, only call get_shard_ranges when the remote indicates
that it has shard ranges for us to sync -- this reduces the number of
requests necessary to bring unsharded replicas in sync.

Change-Id: I32f51f42d76db38271442a261600089404a00f91
Closes-Bug: #1835260

commit_message:
container-replicator: Add a timeout for get_shard_ranges

Previously this had no timeout, which meant that the replicator might
hang and fail to make progress indefinitely while trying to receive
shard ranges.

While we're at it, only call get_shard_ranges when the remote indicates
that it has shard ranges for us to sync -- this reduces the number of
requests necessary to bring unsharded replicas in sync.

Change-Id: I32f51f42d76db38271442a261600089404a00f91
Closes-Bug: #1835260

commit_message:
Mark fullstack test_ha_router_restart_agents_no_packet_lost as unstable

Even after we merged [1] which should fix this failing test,
it is still failing quite often and we don't have root cause yet.

Lets (again) mark it as unstable for now to make our gate more
stable for now.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/664629/

Change-Id: I8ab51afc154a4359d9667112d4563faa82f02fcd
Related-Bug: #1798475

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-21 20:10:27.000000000', 'message': 'Handle registries with incorrect certs correctly

We actually end up allowing registries with incorrect certificates in
the upload code so they get treated the same as inscure registries.
This change updates the return code of the is_insecure_registry to match
how we handle these registries in the image uploader. Additionally, this
means that when the container image prepare code runs, we will correctly
include these registries that have ssl enabled but incorrect
certificates will correctly be included in the
DockerInsecureRegistryAddress setting.

Change-Id: I7fba881645ec2ea167c064be07ed6d4281b7ed3d
Closes-Bug: #1833751

the upload code so they get treated the same as inscure registries.
This change updates the return code of the is_insecure_registry to match
how we handle these registries in the image uploader. Additionally, this
means that when the container image prepare code runs, we will correctly
include these registries that have ssl enabled but incorrect

commit_message:
Handle registries with incorrect certs correctly

We actually end up allowing registries with incorrect certificates in
the upload code so they get treated the same as inscure registries.
This change updates the return code of the is_insecure_registry to match
how we handle these registries in the image uploader. Additionally, this
means that when the container image prepare code runs, we will correctly
include these registries that have ssl enabled but incorrect
certificates will correctly be included in the
DockerInsecureRegistryAddress setting.

Change-Id: I7fba881645ec2ea167c064be07ed6d4281b7ed3d
Closes-Bug: #1833751

Add parameters to set the ip_version for the subnets.
By default ip_version for all networks are 4.

[{'created': '2019-07-08 09:14:02.000000000', 'message': 'Propagate mtu to all subnets

In networking-ovn we map subnets to OVN DHCP_Options
rows (where we store the MTU), but from neutron API perspective,
the MTU is applied per network. So we need update all subnets
thats belong to network to propagade correctly MTU for network.

Closes-Bug: #1816449
Change-Id: Ieddc16e607bccef84316f9ee908e884539c7ed39
(cherry picked from commit 1daffa9634a813ccbcf00a4c4c9dbd2c504d326d)
'}]
commit_message:
Propagate mtu to all subnets

In networking-ovn we map subnets to OVN DHCP_Options
rows (where we store the MTU), but from neutron API perspective,
the MTU is applied per network. So we need update all subnets
thats belong to network to propagade correctly MTU for network.

Closes-Bug: #1816449
Change-Id: Ieddc16e607bccef84316f9ee908e884539c7ed39
(cherry picked from commit 1daffa9634a813ccbcf00a4c4c9dbd2c504d326d)

commit_message:
Check NetApp SnapRestore license for pools

Added check to validate SnapRestore license for
NetApp ONTAP pools before setting revert_to_snapshot_support
to true/false for the respective pool.
This was always set to True before.

Change-Id: I4750d28c8acfe6d68a91e129e767c6e8607e6a75
Closes-Bug: #1678524

commit_message:
Removes temporary fix for doc generation

A temporary fix was added to get around a bug in how pbr handles
its autodoc_tree_index_modules setting. Since this bug is fixed we no
longer need the work around.

This change is needed since the workaround is now incompatible with the
latest version of Sphinx.

See also[1][2].

[1] https://review.opendev.org/191633
[2] https://review.opendev.org/121667

Change-Id: Idf9dc73d99b4233f49effe24aa047959b1a2ef2c

commit_message:
Cleanup keystone items

The keystone_paste_ini provider is being removed so we don't
need to include it anymore. Additionally some of the
kesytone::wsgi::apache options are being removed (like admin_port).

Change-Id: I2f8b377ba7eb472e6c229e425b3e5c42d7ec82ce
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/658381/

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-05 16:40:17.000000000', 'message': 'Refactor qos_plugin._extend_port_resource_request

In order to speed up the port collection, some DB calls
have been deleted in the extended function
"QoSPlugin._extend_port_resource_request".

With the parent commit, the port DB/OVO object now has the
network QoS policy ID, making the network retrieval unneeded.

In this refactor the QoS policy is collected from the DB only
if a valid QoS policy ID exists, bound to the port or to the
network. This reduces the number of QoS objects collection to
one or zero.

Change-Id: Iadf704c00378da99c502dca3e3b79796c368cac7
Closes-Bug: #1834484
(cherry picked from commit 8b00349a63c65e04b3d188366245234e880b7f60)
'}]
commit_message:
Refactor qos_plugin._extend_port_resource_request

In order to speed up the port collection, some DB calls
have been deleted in the extended function
"QoSPlugin._extend_port_resource_request".

With the parent commit, the port DB/OVO object now has the
network QoS policy ID, making the network retrieval unneeded.

In this refactor the QoS policy is collected from the DB only
if a valid QoS policy ID exists, bound to the port or to the
network. This reduces the number of QoS objects collection to
one or zero.

Change-Id: Iadf704c00378da99c502dca3e3b79796c368cac7
Closes-Bug: #1834484
(cherry picked from commit 8b00349a63c65e04b3d188366245234e880b7f60)

[{'created': '2019-07-05 14:10:44.000000000', 'message': 'Add qos_network_policy_id to Port OVO

Added field "qos_network_policy_id" to Port OVO. This parameter
will be used to retrieve the QoS policy bound to the port network.
This reduces the number of calls to the database by creating a join
between the QosNetworkPolicyBinding table and the Port table, based
on the network ID.

This backref association is not persistent (marked as "viewonly").
This relationship is using for loading the QoS policy ID of the
port network in the Port OVO.

Related-Bug: #1834484

Change-Id: I219a925d5e269b8c73a0481daa879d72c399fd8f
(cherry picked from commit 66fca96e5293040d23fa76380ba3f88b4117a5d7)
'}]
commit_message:
Add qos_network_policy_id to Port OVO

Added field "qos_network_policy_id" to Port OVO. This parameter
will be used to retrieve the QoS policy bound to the port network.
This reduces the number of calls to the database by creating a join
between the QosNetworkPolicyBinding table and the Port table, based
on the network ID.

This backref association is not persistent (marked as "viewonly").
This relationship is using for loading the QoS policy ID of the
port network in the Port OVO.

Related-Bug: #1834484

Change-Id: I219a925d5e269b8c73a0481daa879d72c399fd8f
(cherry picked from commit 66fca96e5293040d23fa76380ba3f88b4117a5d7)

commit_message:
NetApp cDOT driver switch volume efficiency

cDOT compression requires that deduplication is enabled.
Reflect that in update_volume_efficiency_attributes
method, which is now also used for create_volume.

Closes-Bug: #1778022
Change-Id: I1aa05aa07b1cb64c44b1f654ee77b620b6c5e6d0
(cherry picked from commit 04aa4ba141d7a78ca5a924432cd2ddc7494a2c78)
(cherry picked from commit d509dbb5e9532769b4e46b7c71433ab4099c808a)

commit_message:
Sync Sphinx requirement

1. Sync sphinx dependency with global requirements. It caps python 2 since
sphinx 2.0 no longer supports Python 2.7.
2. Update some URLs to latest
3. Remove unncessary "=="

Closes-Bug: #1835804
Change-Id: I36fbb56a56832d535facd9bff25d352c8f0274a1

revisions:

or "started".

This change addresses comment in this change:
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/669365/1/tasks/config.yml@14

Change-Id: Ic25772c04047bcd3aaa3e8abc5b947feb66bcbbb
'}]
commit_message:
Avoid hard-coded value in a generic ansible role

The service will be enabled if and only if its state is set to "running"
or "started".

This change addresses comment in this change:
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/669365/1/tasks/config.yml@14

Change-Id: Ic25772c04047bcd3aaa3e8abc5b947feb66bcbbb

commit_message:
update example zuul job parent

The zuul job parent was not correct and if someone was following
the documentation importing or creating a new role, manually or
using the automation, their initial commit would not work. This
change updates the parent job name so that its functional on day
one.

Change-Id: Ic614d166451032c1b7b650a4d37a4e3a89afa629
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

subject: Disallow SSLv2, SSLv3 and TLS1.0 in stunnel for FedRAMP compliance.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 6449, 'name': 'Chris Jones', 'email': 'cmsj@tenshu.net', 'username': 'cmsj'}, {'_account_id': 10873, 'name': 'Juan Antonio Osorio Robles', 'email': 'jaosorior@redhat.com', 'username': 'ejuaoso'}, {'_account_id': 20778, 'name': 'Damien Ciabrini', 'email': 'dciabrin@redhat.com', 'username': 'dciabrin'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 27427, 'name': 'David Peacock', 'email': 'dpeacock@redhat.com', 'username': 'davidjpeacock'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 6449, 'date': '2018-04-10 16:59:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 20778, 'date': '2018-04-10 17:09:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 20778, 'date': '2018-04-10 17:11:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

LGTM, but I'd like to deploy TLS Everywhere to verify that stunnel client like Redis is configured properly before +1"}, {'account_id': 6449, 'date': '2018-04-10 19:27:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6449, 'date': '2018-04-10 19:27:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2018-04-18 12:00:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

Thanks! that's awesome! I'll test it out"}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2018-04-18 12:00:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2018-04-19 06:06:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: -Code-Review

I tried this out in CentOS and it didn't work. For some reason stunnel is only accepting TLSv1.0 connections (it doesn't accept sslv3, but doesn't accept tlsv1.1 nor tlsv1.2)... this is kinda strange because we have a similar setup for haproxy, which is also based on openssl, and it effectively only takes tlsv1.1 and up with the current setup."}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2018-04-19 06:09:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Also note that both the host and the container have a version of openssl that supports TLSv1.2'}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2018-04-19 06:44:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

This is the data from the container:


# stunnel -h
Clients allowed=512000
stunnel 4.56 on x86_64-redhat-linux-gnu platform
Compiled/running with OpenSSL 1.0.1e-fips 11 Feb 2013
Threading:PTHREAD Sockets:POLL,IPv6 SSL:ENGINE,OCSP,FIPS Auth:LIBWRAP
Reading configuration from file -h
Cannot read configuration
 
Syntax:
stunnel [<filename>] ] -fd <n> | -help | -version | -sockets
    <filename>  - use specified config file
    -fd <n>     - read the config file from a file descriptor
    -help       - get config file help
    -version    - display version and defaults
    -sockets    - display default socket options
str_stats: 1 block(s), 3 data byte(s), 58 control byte(s)
()[root@overcloud-controller-0 /]# openssl version
OpenSSL 1.0.2k-fips  26 Jan 2017'}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2018-04-19 08:47:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I tested out this alternative https://review.openstack.org/#/c/562512/'}, {'account_id': 20778, 'date': '2018-04-19 15:16:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> I tested out this alternative https://review.openstack.org/#/c/562512/

So when I'm generating a small stunnel config with maximum debug logs:
debug=7
foreground = yes
[redis]
client = no
accept=172.17.1.15:6666
connect=127.0.0.1:6379
cert=/etc/pki/tls/certs/redis.crt
key=/etc/pki/tls/private/redis.key

I can see that setting options=NO_* makes a difference:
stunnel /tmp/foo.conf 2>&1 | grep 'SSL options set'                                                                                                                 
SSL options set: 0x01000004

With "options=NO_SSLv3" I get:
stunnel /tmp/foo.conf 2>&1 | grep 'SSL options set'
SSL options set: 0x03000004

With both "options=NO_SSLv3" and "options=NO_TLSv1" I get:
SSL options set: 0x07000004

But I don't know how I could easily verify that the cryptos are disabled.
Running "openssl s_client -connect {host}:{port}" seems to always work for me, even if I use option "sslVersion=TLSv1.2" as you mentionned in 
 https://review.openstack.org/#/c/562512/

Any idea?'}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2018-04-19 18:17:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Yes, using openssl s_client -connect {host}:{port} should always work. But you need to specify the TLS version in order to actually verify this. You can do so with flags.

So to verify that TLSv1.2 is used you can do:

openssl s_client -connect {host}:{port} -tls1_2

if you want to verify that TLSv1.0 is not working anymore, you can do:

openssl s_client -connect {host}:{port} -tls1'}, {'account_id': 20778, 'date': '2018-04-19 18:36:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> Yes, using openssl s_client -connect {host}:{port} should always
 > work. But you need to specify the TLS version in order to actually
 > verify this. You can do so with flags.
 > 
 > So to verify that TLSv1.2 is used you can do:
 > 
 > openssl s_client -connect {host}:{port} -tls1_2
 > 
 > if you want to verify that TLSv1.0 is not working anymore, you can
 > do:
 > 
 > openssl s_client -connect {host}:{port} -tls1

Oh sorry, I was unclear. With the following config:
debug=7
foreground = yes
[redis]
client = no
accept=172.17.1.15:6666
connect=127.0.0.1:6379
cert=/etc/pki/tls/certs/redis.crt
key=/etc/pki/tls/private/redis.key
sslVersion=TLSv1.2

I can still connect with TLS1 apparently:
# openssl s_client -connect 127.0.0.1:6379 -tls1
CONNECTED(00000003)
same with sslv3
# openssl s_client -connect 127.0.0.1:6379 -ssl3
CONNECTED(00000003)

Is that expected, or did I run something wrong here?'}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2018-04-19 18:38:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Disallow SSLv2, SSLv3 and TLS1.0 in stunnel for FedRAMP compliance.

We now enforce TLS1.1 or higher for stunnel connections, to meet the
requirements for FedRAMP.

Change-Id: I94f354c057a41abac42ccff501912f81cb905aa2
Related-Bug: #1754368

commit_message:
Add Python 3 Train unit tests

This is a mechanically generated patch to ensure unit testing is in place
for all of the Tested Runtimes for Train.

See the Train python3-updates goal document for details:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/train/python3-updates.html

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/669542

Change-Id: I7add04a3f3d02c5e771088986920b6743234dfee
Story: #2005924
Task: #34235

commit_message:
ceilometer_agent_notification: disable-panko.yaml

ceilometer-agent-notification.yaml updated the
kolla_config section in template file to include
nothing related to panko when disable-panko env file is passed.

Closes-Bug: #1824840

Change-Id: Ia71e80c84449209653609c911fef4cb3cdce5b5c
(cherry picked from commit 8fac4c4334ad2b2ef67040d053a58a9ba8857425)
(cherry picked from commit 9a1491a42fd6679b9222eb22af5844ce3edf5067)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-05 08:35:35.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] Move nova cell v2 discovery to external_post_deploy_tasks

Recent changes for e.g edge scenarios caused intended move of discovery
from controller to bootstrap compute node. The task is triggered by
deploy-identifier to make sure it gets run on any deploy,scale, ... run.
If deploy run is triggered with --skip-deploy-identifier flag, discovery
will not be triggered at and as result causing failures in previously
supported scenarios.
This change moves the host discovery task to external_post_deploy_tasks
that it gets triggered even if --skip-deploy-identifier is used, or
the compute bootstrap node is blacklisted.

Closes-Bug: #1831711

Change-Id: I4bd8489e4f79e3e1bfe9338ed3043241dd605dcb

commit_message:
Move nova cell v2 discovery to deploy_steps_tasks

Recent changes for e.g edge scenarios caused intended move of discovery
from controller to bootstrap compute node. The task is triggered by
deploy-identifier to make sure it gets run on any deploy,scale, ... run.
If deploy run is triggered with --skip-deploy-identifier flag, discovery
will not be triggered at and as result causing failures in previously
supported scenarios.
This change moves the host discovery task to be an ansible
deploy_steps_tasks that it gets triggered even if --skip-deploy-identifier
is used, or the compute bootstrap node is blacklisted.

Closes-Bug: #1831711

Change-Id: I4bd8489e4f79e3e1bfe9338ed3043241dd605dcb

commit_message:
Add new parameter NovaSchedulerLimitTenantsToPlacementAggregate

Add new parameter NovaSchedulerLimitTenantsToPlacementAggregate
allows for configuring scheduler to enable tenant-isolation with
placement, which ensures that hosts in tenant-isolated host
aggregate and availability zones will only be available to
specific set of tenants.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/669252/
Change-Id: Ic1a7ff0996c5cfeec2ca013bc4e5b2eddab0c377

commit_message:
Don't use the z flag in case NovaNfsEnabled is true

Deployment with enabled NFS share for nova ephemeral storage fails. Podman
fails to relable with mounted nfs in /var/lib/nova/instances and container
fail to start with "operation not supported".
This change only sets the z flag for the /var/lib/nova in case nfs is not
enabled for the compute.

Change-Id: I732c0c3e0b3eb1b52f0df58568ec3a42f3d6d1a1
Closes-Bug: #1835503

commit_message:
Use opendev mirror in fortnebula cloud

I did not add openstack.org DNS records for the mirror in this cloud
region so we need to use the opendev name instead.

Change-Id: I4bcc80ca8bfec799f15c06e13c667f121896f8c5

commit_message:
Catch the error if we are not able to connect to the heat client and fetch Overcloud names

If by any reason heat is not able
to fetch the Overcloud stack name
the client will fail.

This submission catch the exception for
not breaking the python client and fail
stating that the stack was not able to be found.

Change-Id: Ia8e77585f82309904960c1d8781158483ed90a69

commit_message:
runner: refactor image_exist

iamge_exist only makes sense in podman where the inspect command
requires the image to be here.

Also, rather than returning a return code, return a bool to make the use
of image_exist simpler in the code.

This patch is preparing the code to have container_exist and re-use the
same logic later.

Change-Id: I9b7f1df0f466f8e5cd44f0c8e4465618fe4fc8a1

commit_message:
Change OS::Heat::*Deployments to OS::Heat:*DeploymentGroup

Those are hidden resource types in heat. Changing these types
would not result in replacement of the resources.

Change-Id: I22d23a8f187263bd36e364f0cd3301c830f3220b

commit_message:
runner: implement container_exist

On podman, we can run "podman container exists" command to check if
whether or not a container does exist.

This will be used later when we'll reduce our usage of "podman inspect".

Change-Id: I6dfbfe9da3d216cadaca77a53a0d5223c9cbd57d

subject: Ensure that OctaviaServerCertsKeyPassphrase is 32-byte long
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3153, 'name': 'Emilien Macchi', 'email': 'emilien@redhat.com', 'username': 'emilienm'}, {'_account_id': 6469, 'name': 'Carlos Gonçalves', 'display_name': 'Carlos Goncalves', 'email': 'cgoncalves@redhat.com', 'username': 'cgoncalves'}, {'_account_id': 6579, 'name': 'Nir Magnezi', 'email': 'nmagnezi@redhat.com', 'username': 'nmagnezi'}, {'_account_id': 6681, 'name': 'Brent Eagles', 'email': 'beagles@redhat.com', 'username': 'beagles'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 25402, 'name': 'Francesco Pantano', 'email': 'fpantano@redhat.com', 'username': 'fmount'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 6579, 'date': '2019-06-22 21:55:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2019-06-23 11:12:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

OctaviaServerCertsKeyPassphrase should be constrained to 32-byte long when set by user.'}, {'account_id': 6579, 'date': '2019-06-23 11:21:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> OctaviaServerCertsKeyPassphrase should be constrained to 32-byte
 > long when set by user.

Thanks for the feedback.
The main agenda of the original patches is to autogenerate the passphrase, not to enable the option for operators to specify their own. 

reference, comments at: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/647467/11/releasenotes/notes/generate-server_certs_key_passphrase-229a677df1b7f6e0.yaml'}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2019-06-23 12:10:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The parameter *is* exposed to users and users *can* set a value.

[vagrant@standalone-1 ~]$ grep OctaviaServerCertsKeyPassphrase standalone_parameters.yaml 
  OctaviaServerCertsKeyPassphrase: 0123456789
[vagrant@standalone-1 ~]$ sudo grep ^server_certs_key_passphrase /var/lib/config-data/puppet-generated/octavia/etc/octavia/octavia.conf 
server_certs_key_passphrase=0123456789'}, {'account_id': 6579, 'date': '2019-06-23 13:45:23.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from OctaviaServerCertsKeyPassphrase-32byte to OctaviaServerCertsKeyPassphrase-32chars'}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2019-06-23 20:01:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Since my previous review, Nir has addressed my comment with patches in puppet-octavia and THT:

https://review.opendev.org/#/q/topic:OctaviaServerCertsKeyPassphrase-32chars

What is missing now is a release note and LP.'}, {'account_id': 6579, 'date': '2019-06-24 08:15:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2019-06-24 08:33:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6579, 'date': '2019-06-30 20:56:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 6579, 'date': '2019-07-01 07:41:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-26 04:55:14.000000000', 'message': "FC: Ignore some HBAs from map for single WWNN

Current FC OS-Brick code only checks for single WWNN to exclude some
HBAs from scanning when we don't receive an initiator_target_map from
the backend.

There are storage arrays,like XtremIO, that due to their architecture
and design have all target ports automatically mapped to LUNs and are
returning the initiator_target_map, but some of those ports may not be
connected to our HBAs, so we end up with another case of bug #1765000.

This patch makes sure that we always check if the target implements
single WWNN, not only when we don't receive the initiator_target_map.

With this we decrease the likelihood of ending with unexpected devices
in our system, because now we will ignore unconnected HBAs (even if
reported in the initiator_target_map) if we are working with single WWNN
target.

Related-Bug: #1765000
Closes-Bug: #1828440
Change-Id: I02c208142f5b342f894666831449243863eccbfe
(cherry picked from commit 70899a9aa3e4bdd3f1b1a7024807390cd55c4958)
(cherry picked from commit 1ee6acb509910d7de1213fb71cd0d6166991609a)
"}]
commit_message:
FC: Ignore some HBAs from map for single WWNN

Current FC OS-Brick code only checks for single WWNN to exclude some
HBAs from scanning when we don't receive an initiator_target_map from
the backend.

There are storage arrays,like XtremIO, that due to their architecture
and design have all target ports automatically mapped to LUNs and are
returning the initiator_target_map, but some of those ports may not be
connected to our HBAs, so we end up with another case of bug #1765000.

This patch makes sure that we always check if the target implements
single WWNN, not only when we don't receive the initiator_target_map.

With this we decrease the likelihood of ending with unexpected devices
in our system, because now we will ignore unconnected HBAs (even if
reported in the initiator_target_map) if we are working with single WWNN
target.

Related-Bug: #1765000
Closes-Bug: #1828440
Change-Id: I02c208142f5b342f894666831449243863eccbfe
(cherry picked from commit 70899a9aa3e4bdd3f1b1a7024807390cd55c4958)
(cherry picked from commit 1ee6acb509910d7de1213fb71cd0d6166991609a)

commit_message:
Add Selenium scripts to network-policy

This adds the scripts to run the Selenium tests
to the network-policy job. Doing this ensures that
the LMA dashboards still come up after a change
to the network policy is made

Change-Id: I9b75610566f032c83dd05966e8d0b08713645fe9

commit_message:
Add egress network policy to LMA services

This change adds and egress network policy to the
LMA services. In order to do this additional endpoints
allowing the service to communicate with the host
namespace after the egress policy was implemented.

Change-Id: I52d7350a2a9900f9e4d61784cbd84f0cd0f1d3c8

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-08 03:28:50.000000000', 'message': 'Support agile samples name

If using common samples, we could only put samples under
api_samples/servers. We will put a lot of samples when we
have more and more microversions.
We add a new param named sample_name so that we can add
samples into api_samples/servers/v2.xx.

Change-Id: I3df835737e302775ec0c0b96e79166919ba5ea2c
'}]
commit_message:
Support agile samples name

If using common samples, we could only put samples under
api_samples/servers. We will put a lot of samples when we
have more and more microversions.
We add a new param named sample_name so that we can add
samples into api_samples/servers/v2.xx.

Change-Id: I3df835737e302775ec0c0b96e79166919ba5ea2c

[{'created': '2019-06-28 20:57:37.000000000', 'message': 'Fix Grafana helm test exception error

Grafana helm test is failing with the below error
"NameError: name 'exception' is not defined"
This is because exception is defined in smaller case. changing
exception to Exception fixes this issue

Change-Id: I533ae822babb4f063242fee1cd42b5b821519b5f
Signed-off-by: Sreejith Punnapuzha <Sreejith.Punnapuzha@outlook.com>

commit_message:
Fix Grafana helm test exception error

Grafana helm test is failing with the below error
"NameError: name 'exception' is not defined"
This is because exception is defined in smaller case. changing
exception to Exception fixes this issue

Change-Id: I533ae822babb4f063242fee1cd42b5b821519b5f
Signed-off-by: Sreejith Punnapuzha <Sreejith.Punnapuzha@outlook.com>

commit_message:
Fix follow up comment of pdf goal

doc is per release version things and sometime
those are updated with the backport changes to
stable branches.

For example nova rocky 18.0.0 and 18.2.0 can have
changes in doc, so pdf for both release should
contain the release version explicitly.

This is fixing the comment given in original goal
proposal patch
- https://review.opendev.org/#/c/647712/8/goals/train/pdf-doc-generation.rst@55

Change-Id: I9c13b89574c1ae9855b49bc9a45ab3756b8b1961

> (1 comment)

I disagree. We have the coverage from those two separate jobs, so we should only make developers run one of them locally. Since py37 is the one more likely to fail, and it's a safe assumption that a passing py37 job will mean py36 will pass, I don't think we should make them both defaults."}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-06-25 13:31:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> > (1 comment)
 > 
 > I disagree. We have the coverage from those two separate jobs, so
 > we should only make developers run one of them locally. Since py37
 > is the one more likely to fail, and it's a safe assumption that a
 > passing py37 job will mean py36 will pass, I don't think we should
 > make them both defaults.

It depends on how people use tox defaults. I personally like to have all py version in default env list which gate tests. But I agree with fungi point[1] of keeping this discussion separate from this goal and can be standardized later.

lgtm'}]

commit_message:
Add Python 3 Train unit tests

This is a mechanically generated patch to ensure unit testing is in place
for all of the Tested Runtimes for Train.

See the Train python3-updates goal document for details:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/train/python3-updates.html

Change-Id: I4f689ee8b9534952ca30db944e547cb7ca74a17f
Story: #2005924
Task: #34208

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-05 08:37:45.000000000', 'message': 'Restructuring the method of vf-representor renaming

The old way of renmaing depended on adding udev rule
before creating vf-representors and so we faced race condition on
uplink representor rename.
So now we are creating vf-representors and after that we adding the
udev rules and trigerring them at the end
Also because the old name of UDEV_RULE_FILE(70-persistent-net.rules) is
used by another module, so we renamed the udev_rule_file to
(80-persistent-os-net-config.rules) and with that way it will override
any previouse rules in (70-persistent-net.rules) and will not any cause
any confustion
Addition to that, we also added a udev rule to make vf-representors
unmanaged by NetworkManager in order to be renamed successfully

Change-Id: I61c59e162bc5d15c063f52612e198d93f4433db1
Closes-Bug: #1830716
(cherry picked from commit 5d44b582b514dd91c14c12614a6d003591876054)
'}]
commit_message:
Restructuring the method of vf-representor renaming

The old way of renmaing depended on adding udev rule
before creating vf-representors and so we faced race condition on
uplink representor rename.
So now we are creating vf-representors and after that we adding the
udev rules and trigerring them at the end
Also because the old name of UDEV_RULE_FILE(70-persistent-net.rules) is
used by another module, so we renamed the udev_rule_file to
(80-persistent-os-net-config.rules) and with that way it will override
any previouse rules in (70-persistent-net.rules) and will not any cause
any confustion
Addition to that, we also added a udev rule to make vf-representors
unmanaged by NetworkManager in order to be renamed successfully

Change-Id: I61c59e162bc5d15c063f52612e198d93f4433db1
Closes-Bug: #1830716
(cherry picked from commit 5d44b582b514dd91c14c12614a6d003591876054)

commit_message:
Restructuring the method of vf-representor renaming

The old way of renmaing depended on adding udev rule
before creating vf-representors and so we faced race condition on
uplink representor rename.
So now we are creating vf-representors and after that we adding the
udev rules and trigerring them at the end
Also because the old name of UDEV_RULE_FILE(70-persistent-net.rules) is
used by another module, so we renamed the udev_rule_file to
(80-persistent-os-net-config.rules) and with that way it will override
any previouse rules in (70-persistent-net.rules) and will not any cause
any confustion
Addition to that, we also added a udev rule to make vf-representors
unmanaged by NetworkManager in order to be renamed successfully

Change-Id: I61c59e162bc5d15c063f52612e198d93f4433db1
Closes-Bug: #1830716
(cherry picked from commit 5d44b582b514dd91c14c12614a6d003591876054)

commit_message:
Remove sheepdog tests from zuul config

The sheepdog project is no longer maintained [0], so this removes the
test configuration as part of an effort to clean up those test
definitions. The glance_store support for sheepdog should also be
deprecated and removed, but that will be done separately.

[0] http://lists.wpkg.org/pipermail/sheepdog/2019-March/068451.html

Change-Id: I79d9dbc8f6ebea381d99e96c4ba4194ba0188b8a
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit a7a6064e7dc4775d08753f029c2589a4586e0f66)

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2019-06-25 15:20:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I brought this up with some OSF staff and one question which arose is whether there are possibly any political concerns around use of an antebellum system. The fact that Hanyu Pinyn supplanted it in 1958 is surely no coincidence, and so it would be good to make sure that our apparent rejection of that choice isn't likely to raise the ire of The Party.

We very nearly ended up with a culturally offensive choice for the M cycle, so I'd prefer not to repeat that mishap."}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2019-06-25 15:50:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1

@Jeremy - I think we will have to be super careful with whatever wins this vote, no matter the spelling  system in use'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2019-06-25 16:13:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I agree, just checking that this romanization system choice isn't itself likely to cause offense."}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2019-06-26 21:01:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> I brought this up with some OSF staff and one question which arose
 > is whether there are possibly any political concerns around use of
 > an antebellum system. The fact that Hanyu Pinyn supplanted it in
 > 1958 is surely no coincidence, and so it would be good to make sure
 > that our apparent rejection of that choice isn't likely to raise
 > the ire of The Party.

I honestly don't know, nor do I really know how to make that determination.

The only thing I can think of is to ask the community, perhaps reach out via Horace.

I don't want to speak for Eric (on CC), and one member of the community isn't representative, but I like to think we wouldn't have gotten that far if the GR system would cause the problem you're describing.

 > We very nearly ended up with a culturally offensive choice for the
 > M cycle, so I'd prefer not to repeat that mishap.

I agree we've already gone to a non-zero amount of work to avoid and be sensitive to that so ... for that to cause the offense we're trying to avoid would be terrible :("}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2019-06-26 21:15:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thanks, I raise it as a possible concern primarily to make sure it's taken into account when reviewers who have familiarity with the cultural nuances involved are providing feedback. To reiterate, to anyone reviewing this who may have some legitimate concern over the political implications of us appearing to choose Gwoyeu Romatzyh over Hanyu Pinyin, please do point this out if it's a risk since most of us lack the perspective and context to make that determination."}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2019-06-26 23:21:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> I brought this up with some OSF staff and one question which arose
 > is whether there are possibly any political concerns around use of
 > an antebellum system. The fact that Hanyu Pinyn supplanted it in
 > 1958 is surely no coincidence, and so it would be good to make sure
 > that our apparent rejection of that choice isn't likely to raise
 > the ire of The Party.
 > 
 > We very nearly ended up with a culturally offensive choice for the
 > M cycle, so I'd prefer not to repeat that mishap.

I don't have personal insight into whether the choice of romanization system would be politically sensitive. I agree with Jeremy that it would be very helpful to hear any concerns on that front.

That said, I have done some basic sanity checks on wikipedia:
1. The People's Republic of China continued the official use of Gwoyeu Romatzyh for 18 years after the Communist Party established control over mainland China and proclaimed the founding of the PRC in 1949.
2. A reading on wikipedia does not suggest explicit political motivation for the change of romanization in 1958.
3. Gwoyeu Romatzyh is not a "western" system, being created in China by a group of linguists.
4. The main creator of Gwoyeu Romatzyh apparently had good standing with the PRC government even though he later emigrated to the US, as evidenced by visits to China in 1973 and 1981 at the invitation of top officials (Zhou En-Lai and Deng Xiao-Ping respectively).
5. Gwoyeu Romatzyh is not in use in Taiwan, avoiding another possible sensitivity.'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2019-06-27 01:04:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thanks Eric! That's all extremely encouraging."}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2019-06-27 01:46:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-06-27 09:28:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-06-27 10:33:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1

Thanks Tony and Eric.'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-06-27 11:32:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1

This can land on 2019-07-01.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-06-27 12:39:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-06-27 12:39:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-07-01 19:25:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote-1

I've taken the time to discuss this with Horace (the OSF's China community manager) regarding the choice of name that we're about to have. They've shared a few concerns with me about the choice that we're making here and I think we should re-consider it before we actually make a decision to go with it.

First of all, it seems that the GR romanization isn't exactly popular in Mainland China and it's actually quite more popular in regions outside of it (in Taiwan) for example.  Therefore, it wouldn't probably be a great image of our community to do that for our chinese contributors.

Secondly, obviously there is a huge lack of vocabulary in terms of word that start with U just because of the language.  Even the few ideas that are listed come with a bit of a complicated spelling overall.

I would like to then propose for us to do something similar to what we did for the Train release.  I would like us to perhaps vote on a resolution to generalize the region to mainland China instead of Shanghai and surrounding areas."}, {'account_id': 23078, 'date': '2019-07-01 19:32:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Mohammed,

A concern with expanding to all of mainland China is that most of the place names that actually start with "U" are in fact in the Mongolian language (to the best of my knowledge). This might bring along its own set of sensitivities.

I'll voice my support for naming the release "Urban"... seems to pay a nice tribute to host city (one of the most urbanized places in the world) while avoiding language issues...'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2019-07-02 03:56:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> I've taken the time to discuss this with Horace (the OSF's China
 > community manager) regarding the choice of name that we're about to
 > have. They've shared a few concerns with me about the choice that
 > we're making here and I think we should re-consider it before we
 > actually make a decision to go with it.
 > 
 > First of all, it seems that the GR romanization isn't exactly
 > popular in Mainland China and it's actually quite more popular in
 > regions outside of it (in Taiwan) for example.  Therefore, it
 > wouldn't probably be a great image of our community to do that for
 > our chinese contributors.

I don't have any insight there, I can say the Eric and I discussed a range of options and this seemed like the best idea.  Yes it's a less popular option for romanization but not unknown.

 > Secondly, obviously there is a huge lack of vocabulary in terms of
 > word that start with U just because of the language.  Even the few
 > ideas that are listed come with a bit of a complicated spelling
 > overall.

Well we have several 'authentic' options in the region defined in this proposal and they were found pretty quickly.  Eric and I felt that using mainland China would give us too many choices.
 
 > I would like to then propose for us to do something similar to what
 > we did for the Train release.  I would like us to perhaps vote on a
 > resolution to generalize the region to mainland China instead of
 > Shanghai and surrounding areas.

To be clear we *always* have at the discretion of the election officials to present the TC with nonconformant names and ask they be included (like we did with Train)  These can trivially include 'authentic' names from outside the geographic region, but As Jeremy (F) points out there are several from near the border with Mongolia

So in short:
a) I don't think that proposing 'Mainland China' as the geographic region is a good idea
b) I think that GR romanisation is the best chance we have to stick with the rules and spirit of the existing process"}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-07-08 11:50:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Rollcall-Vote

Retracting vote if GR romanization is not as popular in mainland China as we originally thought.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-07-08 12:10:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1

After reviewing this, I think it is still acceptable as-is. We should just remove any specific encouragement of GR from the wiki.

Ideally we would seed the options using China-popular options coming out of WeChat, to increase the chances a China-popular name is ultimately chosen.'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-07-08 16:30:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I think I'm okay with this if we agree to drop the GR context."}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-07-08 16:34:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1 Workflow+1

looking at the text, i'm pretty okay with it (on the wiki)."}]

[{'created': '2019-06-23 01:05:51.000000000', 'message': "Add 'U' Release name poll

In order to accommodate the challenges of naming a 'U' release in China
some specific clarifications for acceptable names and geographic region
have been defined.  I believe these are well within the spirit of the
existing criteria.

Specifically:

* Spelling. Currently, the most popular system of romanization of Mandarin
  is the Hanyu Pinyin. Unfortunately, Hanyu Pinyin does not produce any
  romanization which begins with the letter U. In order to allow for U
  names, romanizations produced by other recognized systems shall be
  admissible. For the sake of precision, the accepted systems shall be
  Hanyu Pinyin [PY] (official system of China since 1958), Gwoyeu Romatzyh
  [GR] (official system of China 1929-1958), Wade–Giles romanization, and
  Yale romanization. In practice, only the Gwoyeu Romatzyh system produces
  words starting with the letter U. Reference:
    http://pinyin.info/romanization/compare/gwoyeu_romatzyh.html
* In addition to the romanized names produced by one of the recognized
  romanization systems, traditional and customary spellings of names are also admissible.

We've also defined the geographic region as:
1 The municipality of Shanghai. (Note that Shanghai, being a top level
  administrative division of China, is not part of a province. See
  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Direct-administered_municipalities_of_China#Current_PRC_municipalities
2 All top level administrative divisions of China which borders Shanghai.
  (Jiangsu, Zhejiang)
3 All All top level administrative divisions of China which borders those in
  2 above. (Shandong, Anhui, Jiangxi, Fujian)

Eric Kao has kindly volunteered to provide cultural and language
knowledge.  Thanks Eric.

The timing of this poll is a little different in that I've allowed 1
week between the nominations period closing and the opening of voting.
This is to ensure that there is adequate time to translate the poll and
ensure that all candidate names are correctly classified.

Change-Id: I3f7f64a2a2a6c244fbecb381228c1c1827d79673
"}]
commit_message:
Add 'U' Release name poll

In order to accommodate the challenges of naming a 'U' release in China
some specific clarifications for acceptable names and geographic region
have been defined.  I believe these are well within the spirit of the
existing criteria.

Specifically:

* Spelling. Currently, the most popular system of romanization of Mandarin
  is the Hanyu Pinyin. Unfortunately, Hanyu Pinyin does not produce any
  romanization which begins with the letter U. In order to allow for U
  names, romanizations produced by other recognized systems shall be
  admissible. For the sake of precision, the accepted systems shall be
  Hanyu Pinyin [PY] (official system of China since 1958), Gwoyeu Romatzyh
  [GR] (official system of China 1929-1958), Wade–Giles romanization, and
  Yale romanization. In practice, only the Gwoyeu Romatzyh system produces
  words starting with the letter U. Reference:
    http://pinyin.info/romanization/compare/gwoyeu_romatzyh.html
* In addition to the romanized names produced by one of the recognized
  romanization systems, traditional and customary spellings of names are also admissible.

We've also defined the geographic region as:
1 The municipality of Shanghai. (Note that Shanghai, being a top level
  administrative division of China, is not part of a province. See
  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Direct-administered_municipalities_of_China#Current_PRC_municipalities
2 All top level administrative divisions of China which borders Shanghai.
  (Jiangsu, Zhejiang)
3 All All top level administrative divisions of China which borders those in
  2 above. (Shandong, Anhui, Jiangxi, Fujian)

Eric Kao has kindly volunteered to provide cultural and language
knowledge.  Thanks Eric.

The timing of this poll is a little different in that I've allowed 1
week between the nominations period closing and the opening of voting.
This is to ensure that there is adequate time to translate the poll and
ensure that all candidate names are correctly classified.

Change-Id: I3f7f64a2a2a6c244fbecb381228c1c1827d79673

[{'created': '2019-07-05 08:37:22.000000000', 'message': 'Restructuring the method of vf-representor renaming

The old way of renmaing depended on adding udev rule
before creating vf-representors and so we faced race condition on
uplink representor rename.
So now we are creating vf-representors and after that we adding the
udev rules and trigerring them at the end
Also because the old name of UDEV_RULE_FILE(70-persistent-net.rules) is
used by another module, so we renamed the udev_rule_file to
(80-persistent-os-net-config.rules) and with that way it will override
any previouse rules in (70-persistent-net.rules) and will not any cause
any confustion
Addition to that, we also added a udev rule to make vf-representors
unmanaged by NetworkManager in order to be renamed successfully

Change-Id: I61c59e162bc5d15c063f52612e198d93f4433db1
Closes-Bug: #1830716
(cherry picked from commit 5d44b582b514dd91c14c12614a6d003591876054)
'}]
commit_message:
Restructuring the method of vf-representor renaming

The old way of renmaing depended on adding udev rule
before creating vf-representors and so we faced race condition on
uplink representor rename.
So now we are creating vf-representors and after that we adding the
udev rules and trigerring them at the end
Also because the old name of UDEV_RULE_FILE(70-persistent-net.rules) is
used by another module, so we renamed the udev_rule_file to
(80-persistent-os-net-config.rules) and with that way it will override
any previouse rules in (70-persistent-net.rules) and will not any cause
any confustion
Addition to that, we also added a udev rule to make vf-representors
unmanaged by NetworkManager in order to be renamed successfully

Change-Id: I61c59e162bc5d15c063f52612e198d93f4433db1
Closes-Bug: #1830716
(cherry picked from commit 5d44b582b514dd91c14c12614a6d003591876054)

Add retries to ansible galaxy install for all envs

Galaxy install often fails in CI, scuppering an otherwise good run.

commit_message:
Ensure service is enabled

With older tripleo versions, we did disable the service since we were
using ntpd.
If we upgrade from a version using ntpd, the chronyd service won't be
active upon reboot.

Change-Id: Ic59374afdf5ace02ba8243f5163d0950e527ec52
Closes-Bug: #1835368

commit_message:
Manage oslo_middleware/max_request_body_size

So that we can increase it from the default 114688

Useful in case for example the OS-Federation mapping is too large.

If this limit is breached keystone will return a 413 Entity Too Large
and not log anything to keystone.log.

Closes-Bug: #1835161

Change-Id: If9fc5c0bb5d6216b8656ee1673e1812c543de305
Signed-off-by: Johan Guldmyr <johan.guldmyr@csc.fi>
(cherry picked from commit a60980f3da715b5d4ac986ae515e5aed88b35b74)

commit_message:
Manage oslo_middleware/max_request_body_size

So that we can increase it from the default 114688

Useful in case for example the OS-Federation mapping is too large.

If this limit is breached keystone will return a 413 Entity Too Large
and not log anything to keystone.log.

Closes-Bug: #1835161

Change-Id: If9fc5c0bb5d6216b8656ee1673e1812c543de305
Signed-off-by: Johan Guldmyr <johan.guldmyr@csc.fi>
(cherry picked from commit a60980f3da715b5d4ac986ae515e5aed88b35b74)

commit_message:
PowerMax Driver - Metro ODE Support

PowerMax for Cinder now supports extending in-use Metro RDF
enabled volumes using Online Device Expansion.  This
submission implements this new feature.

Change-Id: I5342cbd64d33c38a68c92e4e56cbfce8aaa621c3
Implements: blueprint powermax-metro-ode

My testbed had some issues w/ networking.  Seems to be working now.  FWIW, I did add 'recheck linstor' as well as 'recheck' for CI trigger.  I am continuing to improve my build setup in the mean time.  The last CI result is at http://us.linbit.com:8080/CI-LINSTOR/42/963/  I will bug you guys after a good recheck .  Thank you."}, {'account_id': 28940, 'date': '2019-01-31 19:53:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-01-31 20:02:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

"recheck" should definitely not be used for your third party CI trigger. That is what zuul triggers off of, so if you want to just rerun your third party CI, that will end up causing all of the check queue jobs to be run again, and all third party CI that run when they see a +1 from zuul.

Make sure you support our documented third party CI recheck trigger:

https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Cinder/tested-3rdParty-drivers#How_do_I_trigger_my_CI_to_rerun_on_gerrit_comments.3F'}, {'account_id': 28940, 'date': '2019-01-31 20:31:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Thank you for the info.  I updated the trigger filter accordingly.  I rechecked because the first gate check timed out on tempest-full.  Now it just failed on lower-constrains.  I guess I will try later when it's quiet."}, {'account_id': 26537, 'date': '2019-01-31 20:46:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-03 11:54:36.000000000', 'message': 'luks: Explicitly use the luks1 type to ensure LUKS v1 is used

I152fe10ff5a3131950b789d3fd4efa15c554ff09 attempted to ensure LUKS
volumes were formatted using the LUKS v1 header format by using a type
of `luks`. However from cryptsetup 2.1.0 (incorrectly referenced as
2.0.6 in the previous change) this type can actually refer to the newer
LUKS v2 header format in environments where cryptsetup has not complied
with the `--with-default-luks-format=LUKS1` build time configuration
option [1].

This change now explicitly uses the luks1 type when formatting a device
to ensure the correct LUKS v1 header format is used.

[1] https://gitlab.com/cryptsetup/cryptsetup/blob/master/docs/v2.1.0-ReleaseNotes

Closes-Bug: #1834851
Change-Id: I0010e9014c06a3a812d24d9d5ef598425ac5d5d4
(cherry picked from commit 97b085f448e15269c28ed8adc60601894c470747)
'}]
commit_message:
luks: Explicitly use the luks1 type to ensure LUKS v1 is used

I152fe10ff5a3131950b789d3fd4efa15c554ff09 attempted to ensure LUKS
volumes were formatted using the LUKS v1 header format by using a type
of `luks`. However from cryptsetup 2.1.0 (incorrectly referenced as
2.0.6 in the previous change) this type can actually refer to the newer
LUKS v2 header format in environments where cryptsetup has not complied
with the `--with-default-luks-format=LUKS1` build time configuration
option [1].

This change now explicitly uses the luks1 type when formatting a device
to ensure the correct LUKS v1 header format is used.

[1] https://gitlab.com/cryptsetup/cryptsetup/blob/master/docs/v2.1.0-ReleaseNotes

Closes-Bug: #1834851
Change-Id: I0010e9014c06a3a812d24d9d5ef598425ac5d5d4
(cherry picked from commit 97b085f448e15269c28ed8adc60601894c470747)

commit_message:
Use oslo_db.sqlalchemy.test_fixtures

Inheriting classes from oslo_db.tests.sqlalchemy.test_base was
deprecated, this patch switches test base to oslotest and use new
fixtures from test_fixtures of oslo.db. Unused functions were removed.

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/545874 is referenced to make this
change.

Change-Id: I4db805f6fceae6ffd530e69ba0a0f0c40b5b7979

keystonemiddleware, such as pkiz token offline validation,
as well as associated tests.

In facter 3.x, the networking facts are in a complex hash. Previously
the interface facts where flat so we would lookup the vars. This change
first tries the facter 2.x lookup before falling back to the facter 3.x
syntax.

commit_message:
Fix interface_for_ip for newer facter versions

In facter 3.x, the networking facts are in a complex hash. Previously
the interface facts where flat so we would lookup the vars. This change
first tries the facter 2.x lookup before falling back to the facter 3.x
syntax.

Change-Id: I260b18ae3479da4f5176027d4b26b3e1c6b22063
Closes-Bug: #1812938

[{'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-05-22 14:15:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2019-05-22 15:27:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

(3 comments)

Needs tweaking as per comments.

Sorry I messed up my slides :('}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2019-05-23 12:45:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-05-23 21:13:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-05-23 21:14:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2019-05-24 01:28:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

Thanks

Looks good to me.'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2019-05-24 16:12:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2019-05-30 19:32:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

Oh, we should probably add a lower-constraints file to the repo so this will actually work out of the box.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-06-17 16:30:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Yup, good move but you need a lower-constraints here'}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-06-18 16:53:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

OK thanks - please can one of you suggest where I should get the correct lower-constraints.txt from, and also how to prevent it rapidly bit-rotting?'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2019-06-18 17:08:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Since there are so few default requirements, I just wrote one by hand for the oslo-cookiecutter version of this patch: https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo-cookiecutter/src/branch/master/oslo.%7b%7bcookiecutter.module_name%7d%7d/lower-constraints.txt

That will probably work here too.

Might also be useful to pull in the test script we have in oslo-cookiecutter so we can verify that the tox targets actually work when we generate a new repo: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/662508/3/tools/test_tox_targets.sh

Once that series merges we'll be gating oslo-cookiecutter on it."}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2019-06-18 17:10:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Adam Spiers wrote:

> OK thanks - please can one of you suggest where I should get the
> correct lower-constraints.txt from, and also how to prevent it
> rapidly bit-rotting?

Part of the challenge is that any lower-constraints.txt is going to be very project-specific (determined not only by the project's dependencies but which releases of those dependencies introduced features the project relies on). Would it be sufficient to include an "empty" lower-constraints.txt which just contains comments pointing to documentation for how a project would go about creating an appropriate one for themselves? That should make the tox env work, though would be essentially equivalent to a normal unconstrained run.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-06-18 17:12:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I was just going to suggest the same thing as fungi. I think that's probably the most reasonable option for a cookie cutter setup."}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-06-19 12:16:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Thanks folks - I love that idea, but it has one tiny snag: I can't find any such docs to point to which explain how to set up a lower-constraints.txt correctly ;-)  Does it not exist, or am I just looking in the wrong places?  If it doesn't then unfortunately I don't know enough to be able to write it myself ..."}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-06-19 12:33:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I think for brand new projects, the process would basically be to run the normal upper constraint jobs and use the output from pip freeze to initially populate the lower-constraints.txt file.

I do think this could use some better documentation, but I'm not aware of any right now."}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-06-19 12:57:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Thanks Sean!  Where would such documentation be best placed - the project creator's guide, or project team guide?"}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-06-19 12:58:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Andi - you may be interested in the discussion here.'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2019-06-19 15:59:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

It looks like there is a tool to generate lower-constraints automatically: https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/src/branch/master/tools/fix-lower-constraints.py

I'm not sure if that's the one we used to generate lower-constraints for all of the existing projects, but it seems like a good place to start."}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-06-19 20:35:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-06-24 09:27:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2019-07-08 15:19:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Add a testenv for lower-constraints

Give projects a testenv for testing lower constraints by default, as
suggested by Tony in the recent Requirements project update in Denver:

    https://youtu.be/55ZlXiuiLCo?t=159

and by Dirk:

    https://review.opendev.org/#/c/657444/2/%257B%257Bcookiecutter.repo_name%257D%257D/tox.ini@8

Change-Id: I2456a477ab3f36d2b63420c502bc5409770a4712

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-05 10:32:47.000000000', 'message': "Wait for all compute services before cell discovery

There is a race condition during nova deploy since we wait for at least
one compute service to register itself before performing cells v2 host
discovery.  It's quite possible that other compute nodes will not yet
have registered and will therefore not be discovered. This leaves them
not mapped into a cell, and results in the following error if the
scheduler picks one when booting an instance:

Host 'xyz' is not mapped to any cell

The problem has been exacerbated by merging a fix [1][2] for a nova race
condition, which disabled the dynamic periodic discovery mechanism in
the nova scheduler.

This change fixes the issue by waiting for all expected compute services
to register themselves before performing host discovery. This includes
both virtualised compute services and bare metal compute services.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/kolla-ansible/+bug/1832987
[2] https://review.opendev.org/665554

Change-Id: I2915e2610e5c0b8d67412e7ec77f7575b8fe9921
Closes-Bug: #1835002
(cherry picked from commit c38dd767118164aae37613d557ed23691813f617)
"}]
commit_message:
Wait for all compute services before cell discovery

There is a race condition during nova deploy since we wait for at least
one compute service to register itself before performing cells v2 host
discovery.  It's quite possible that other compute nodes will not yet
have registered and will therefore not be discovered. This leaves them
not mapped into a cell, and results in the following error if the
scheduler picks one when booting an instance:

Host 'xyz' is not mapped to any cell

The problem has been exacerbated by merging a fix [1][2] for a nova race
condition, which disabled the dynamic periodic discovery mechanism in
the nova scheduler.

This change fixes the issue by waiting for all expected compute services
to register themselves before performing host discovery. This includes
both virtualised compute services and bare metal compute services.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/kolla-ansible/+bug/1832987
[2] https://review.opendev.org/665554

Change-Id: I2915e2610e5c0b8d67412e7ec77f7575b8fe9921
Closes-Bug: #1835002
(cherry picked from commit c38dd767118164aae37613d557ed23691813f617)

[{'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2019-06-24 19:13:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-06-25 11:25:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-06-26 08:42:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Ditto as other patches'}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2019-06-26 18:40:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2019-06-26 19:59:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Dmitiry feel free to ingore this patch update. I didn't understand "ditto as other patches" until later. I know you want to stick with py3. Note though, I think that defaults to whatever py3 is default on the developer's system, so the developer could be running py34 and gate will be running py36/py37.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-06-27 10:25:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Note though, I think that defaults to whatever py3 is default on the developer's system, so the developer could be running py34 and gate will be running py36/py37.

Exactly. And we cannot change that. I'd like to avoid the situation when 'tox' fails because a developer has python 3.6 only."}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2019-07-02 18:49:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Fair enough and good point, but time to upgrade if you don't have py37 :)"}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2019-07-03 14:13:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

> Fair enough and good point, but time to upgrade if you don't have
 > py37 :)

True, but depending on the distribution, that is far harder than one would think. The point of the gate is that it does the right thing in the end for us. It tests and blocks on the versions that we need it to. If a developer is off by one version for running unit tests than I think that is okay as long as the gate still does the right thing and blocks anything not compatible with newer versions."}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2019-07-05 14:31:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2019-07-05 14:32:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I should say "moved so far" as the python3 goal for train is still progressing.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-07-06 19:33:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2019-07-08 14:48:36.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2019-06-27 22:32:53.000000000', 'message': "[WIP] base job testing

This change converts the TripleO-Ansible test process to using native zuul.
After a long discussion about the current test process [0] it has been
determined that most folks using tox do so on a local workstation and
would not expect the local system to be modified in anyway.

To ensure we're not creating a situation where a developer runs tox on a
local system with a job that may require local modifications of the
local system the current test structure has been replaced with a native
zuul base job.

In support of using a native job, a bindep file and script have been
added, which will ensure our package dependecies are resolved in the
job pre stage.

Change-Id: Ia1f3d479f3ac447d125169d08c78aaccfeacea3a
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2019-06-27 22:43:35.000000000', 'message': "[WIP] Convert tox to native zuul

This change converts the TripleO-Ansible test process to using native zuul.
After a long discussion about the current test process [0] it has been
determined that most folks using tox do so on a local workstation and
would not expect the local system to be modified in anyway.

To ensure we're not creating a situation where a developer runs tox on a
local system with a job that may require modifications of the system,
the current test structure has been replaced with a native zuul
base job.

This change opens the door for us to add tox jobs later which may be in
support of the native jobs we're running now.

In support of using a native job, a bindep file and script have been
added, which will ensure our package dependecies are resolved in the
job pre stage.

"}, {'created': '2019-06-28 04:23:33.000000000', 'message': "Convert tox to native zuul

This change converts the TripleO-Ansible test process to using native zuul.
After a long discussion about the current test process [0] it has been
determined that most folks using tox do so on a local workstation and
would not expect the local system to be modified when tox is envoked

To ensure we're not creating a situation where a developer runs tox with a
job that may require modifications of the system the current test
structure has been replaced with a native zuul `base` job.

This change opens the door for us to add tox jobs later which may be added
in support of the native jobs we're running now.

In support of using a native job, a bindep file and script have been
added, which will ensure our package dependecies are resolved in the
job pre stage allowing us to benifit from internal zuul retry logic which
will assist in job execution time.

Documentation has been added to the contributing section to highlight
the role development process and how folks can test things locally.

The test_json_error role was updated to set required configuration
for that specific role, which was being passed in via tox before.

[0] - http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23tripleo/latest.log.html#t2019-06-27T14:01:13

commit_message:
Convert tox to native zuul

This change converts the TripleO-Ansible test process to using native zuul.
After a long discussion about the current test process [0] it has been
determined that most folks using tox do so on a local workstation and
would not expect the local system to be modified when envoked.

To ensure we're not creating a situation where a developer runs tox with a
job that may require modifications of the system the current test
structure has been replaced with a native zuul `base` job.

> This change opens the door for us to add tox jobs later which may be
  added in support of the native jobs we're running now.

> The test_json_error role was updated to set required configuration
  for that specific role, which was being passed in via tox before.

Documentation has been added to the contributing section to highlight
the role development process and how folks can test things locally using
a script which will mimic the zuul job runtime.

[0] - http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23tripleo/latest.log.html#t2019-06-27T14:01:13

Change-Id: Ia1f3d479f3ac447d125169d08c78aaccfeacea3a
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

This change is related to I886f2b8ac7092d9b3da38852e92a615d5666eea7
and Ibcdbe2605a7cabe3a5ef8245b4460c8f70220989.

Related-Bug: #1833942

commit_message:
Deprecate oslo::middleware related parameters in ::nova::metadata

enable_proxy_headers_parsing should not only be configurabe if
!$nova_metadata_wsgi_enabled , Therefore it needs to be moved
outside the condition.
But at the moment enable_proxy_headers_parsing can also be set via
::nova::metadata which conficts.
This change deprecates oslo::middleware related parameters
enable_proxy_headers_parsing and and max_request_body_size in
::nova::metadata. In future ::nova::api should be used instead.

Change-Id: I0f138bf278931ac21d228251cc1da44638da915c

commit_message:
Expose limit_tenants_to_placement_aggregate parameter

Add support for configuring scheduler parameter option
'limit_tenants_to_placement_aggregate' to enable tenant
isolation with placement.

Change-Id: I37ce0633b3b56563f373fadfb74820b2896d6734

commit_message:
[CI] Add bindep.txt

Bindep is a tool for checking the presence of binary
packages needed to use an application / library. It
started life as a way to make it easier to set up a
development environment for OpenStack projects.

Infra has been looking to drop the global
bindep_fallback.txt [1][2] file for all
OpenStack projects, they recommend that projects
maintain their own with packages as necessary.

This commit is not a clean cherry-pick.
DevStack for CentOS is currently broken. See
bug 1833696 [3]. The LVM job will be fixed
by a subsequent commit to this branch.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-infra/2018-April/005926.html
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-June/006888.html
[3] https://launchpad.net/bugs/1833696
Change-Id: I1824f132b0ffadc6c9179582d37295f3abed355f
(cherry picked from commit 1709fd7fc222f81bcbedc05e683d2eec5337edcc)
(cherry picked from commit 6ac1730127ddf2f8113e791c3740909bbe05837d)
(cherry picked from commit 4fbe70fbb6c12eb06bc026e043ed2a27572b5da1)

commit_message:
swift: ensure we get rsyslog state "--check" mode

Ensure that the logging forwarding tasks do not fail in ansible check
mode, and we make sure the rsyslog_config is actually defined.

Change-Id: Ifaf692643f21f2ae30557b251ae58a9b32fbb143
Closes-Bug: #1835415
